newsitem.title: UK: GOLF-WOODS LOSES HIS CHANCE, CLARKE LEADS AT OPEN.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-WOODS LOSES HIS CHANCE, CLARKE LEADS AT OPEN.

text.p: Tiger Woods looked to have lost all chance of capturing the British Open title when he took a quadruple bogey eight on the 10th hole at Royal Troon in the second round on Friday.

Northern Irishman Darren Clarke sprinted into a clear lead as titleholder Tom Lehman, who shot an opening 74, faded when he took a triple-bogey seven at the second which included a two-shot penalty for not replacing his marker on the green.
World number one Woods laboured on the early greens, where he made three-putt bogeys at the third and fifth holes, and had a disastrous experience on the 438-yard 10th.

His drive was fine but his second went through the green into an almost unplayable lie in a bush. He tried to hack out but moved the ball only three inches and his fourth flew almost into another bush.
The 21-year-old Masters champion then pitched over the green, chipped back on and two-putted for an eight.
Woods had struggled earlier despite conditions perfect for good scoring, his two bogeys cancelling out birdies on the two long holes.
He three-putted both greens, missing second putts of three feet at the third and four feet on the fifth.
Lehman moved his ball marker as it was in the line of a playing partner's putt and did not move it back when it was his turn, an elementary error calling for a two-shot penalty.
But he recovered with birdies at the fourth, fifth and eighth to stay alive at three over par.
The burly Clarke raced to a four-under front nine of 32 to reach eight under for the tournament and stayed that way through the 14th.
Clarke, 28, who is certain to make his Ryder Cup debut for Europe against the United States at Valderrama in September, was in sizzling form.
The joint overnight leader birdied the first two holes from 12 and 11 feet and the long fourth after reaching the green in two and two-putting.
He bogeyed the short fifth and eighth holes after missing the green on the right side at the fifth and hitting into a bunker on eight.
But the 577-yard sixth provided another birdie, his second stopping 25 yards short of the green from where he putted up to six feet and holed.
He holed from 12 and 15 feet for birdies at the seventh and ninth, dropped one at the 10th and birdied the 14th where he holed from off the green.
Jesper Parnevik, the U.S.-based Swede who was second in the 1994 Open at Turnberry, moved up to second here after following on from his fine finish on Thursday.
He birdied the last three holes then for a 70 and after a bogey five at the first on Friday he picked up five shots by the 11th to stand three strokes behind Clarke.
The Swede's surge included an eagle at the fourth hole.
Co-overnight leader Jim Furyk dropped back after a bogey six at the fourth, a wasted opportunity. He drove into a bunker, could only pitch out and missed the green with his third shot.
The American dropped another at the seventh but got one back at the 126-yard Postage Stamp eighth with a two as his playing partner, Dennis Edlund of Sweden, made a hole in one.
Another Swede, amateur Daniel Olsson, then aced the 210-yard fifth with a five iron to become the third player from his country to score an ace this week. Pierre Fulke did so at the 14th on Thursday.
